summary: A letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys at Cohen & Gresser LLP to the government prosecutors, complaining about the failure to provide readable discovery materials to Maxwell while she is detained at the MDC. The letter details ongoing issues with unreadable files, the processing of thousands of images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties, and access restrictions due to COVID-19 protocols.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused individual detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), whose defense team is demanding proper access to discovery materials for her case preparation.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP who signed the letter, representing Ghislaine Maxwell and detailing the discovery access issues to the government.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the letter, part of Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the letter, part of Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the letter, part of Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the person whose residences in New York and the Virgin Islands were searched, resulting in the seizure of thousands of images that are part of the discovery materials.

connections.description: The discovery materials include images seized from Epstein's residences, and Maxwell is charged in connection with activities involving Epstein.
Everdell is a defense attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Maxwell in her criminal case.
Cohen is a defense attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the letter, representing Maxwell.
Both are attorneys at Cohen & Gresser LLP working on Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team.

events.title: Court-ordered discovery deadline
events.description: The deadline set by the court for the government to provide discovery materials to the defense, which the government had not met as of the date of this letter.

events.title: Discovery issues conference call
events.description: A conference call between defense counsel and government prosecutors to discuss problems with the readability of discovery materials provided to Maxwell.

events.title: Follow-up discovery conference call
events.description: Another conference call to further discuss discovery issues, where defense counsel reiterated that the government's proposed solutions were inadequate.

locations: Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York
Jeffrey Epstein's residences in the Virgin Islands
keyFacts: The government had failed to provide a complete, readable set of discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell over five weeks past the court-ordered August 21, 2020 deadline.

Discovery included approximately 40,000 non-nude photographs and thousands of nude or partially nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the Virgin Islands pursuant to search warrants.
COVID-19 restrictions prevented the U.S. Marshals from producing pretrial detainees to proffer rooms, complicating Maxwell's access to Highly Confidential documents.
The defense team had catalogued defects in prior productions and spent hours trying to correct government errors, while Maxwell had lost over a month of review time.
The letter marks the government's third attempt to produce a readable set of discovery, with the defense having little confidence it would fix the errors.
